author: sky.cactus
content: One potential problem is gaining adoption of this new transaction type.  If all it does is protect the network from an obscure attack vector, it is possible that no wallets will implement support for it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, there is a weak incentive for wallets to backdate transactions so if such an attack does occur, their transactions get included earlier.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, my guess is that no reasonable wallet would actually do this because there is some marginal risk to their users for getting "historical inclusion".  But it exemplifies that there is effectively zero incentive for wallets to accurately set the timestamp as "latest block timestamp +1".

author: sky.cactus
content: How would you become canonical head here?  Wouldn't it require an active attacker who intentionally is withholding attestations and who controls significant validator power?

author: sky.cactus
content: It also feels like this classifies for social slashing under the condition of "not following fork choice rules", though it is a bit of a stretch compared to censorship attacks.

author: potuz
content: there are different ways of achieving this, the most straightforward one is if you hold multiple consecutive slots and a significant stake

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, the attacker is using this to unblind builder blocks.  I see.  That is clever.

author: sky.cactus
content: So submit header, but don't attest, then once you see the block you can build a sibling to it (rather than a child) in the next slot but where the attacker extracts the MEV themself rather than letting the builder receive the rewards.

author: sky.cactus
content: This could even be "decentralized", where a large staker intentionally withholds their attestations and they tell builders "we accept children or siblings to current latest".

author: potuz
content: That is one way, but there is no need to actually miss a block. In the example I gave above, if the attacker holds n and n+3 for example he can achieve this without the need to miss n. If he also holds n+4 he needs less stake, if he holds also n+5 even less, and so on

author: sky.cactus
content: Then they just pick the one with the highest reward and use proposer boost and their large stake to get their block preferred as next head.

author: sky.cactus
content: Only requires 20% of all stake IIRC.

author: potuz
content: There are worse things that what I am describing here, but anyway, I want to get an answer as to the practicability of this mod of simply adding the timestamp to the transaction, all I am seeing against it so far is minor things

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the biggest issue is adoption.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is very unlikely that you'll convince people to deprecate legacy transactions or any of the existing transaction types, and wallets are *incredibly* slow to adopt features that don't directly help their users.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't know if *any* wallet has implemented 2930 for example.

author: sky.cactus
content: And without adoption this ends up being "a lot" (every change is a lot of work) of work with no benefit.
